item.title: Out-of-distribution generalisation via diluted causality
item.description:
• Paper recently accepted to AISTATS 2025.

Description

The term diluted causality is taken from Bühlmann (2018) and was suggested by Ed George. It aims to capture the idea that while causal mechanisms are invariant to any kind of perturbation or intervention, a weaker form of invariance—diluted causality—might often be preferred by restricting the set of potential interventions, especially when the objective is predictive generalization.

This project aims to better understand the relationship between causality, invariance, and out-of-distribution generalization. It builds on the great work of Peter Bühlmann, Nicolai Meinshausen, Jonas Peters, Dominik Rothenhäusler, Rune Christiansen, and others.
